desc: 0<|x|<1/{1+sum_{i=1}^n |a_i|} prove that Q(x)/x^k is strictly increasing
problem:
\begin{problem*}{}{}
  Let $k$, $n$ and $r$ be positive integers.
  \begin{enumerate}[(a)]
    \item Let $Q(x)=x^k+a_1x^{k+1}+\dots+a_nx^{k+n}$
      be a polynomial with real coefficients.
      Show that the function $\frac{Q(x)}{x^k}$
      is strictly positive for all real $x$ satisfying
      \[0<|x|<\frac1{1+\sum\limits_{i=1}^n |a_i|}.\]

    \item Let $P(x)=b_0+b_1x+\dots+b_rx^r$ be a
      non-zero polynomial with real coefficients.
      Let $m$ be the smallest number such that
      $b_m \neq 0$. Prove that the graph of $y=P(x)$
      cuts the $x$-axis at the origin
      (i.e., $P$ changes signs at $x=0$) if and only
      if $m$ is an odd integer.
  \end{enumerate}
\end{problem*}
solution:
\aopssoln{lifeismathematics}{15}{https://aops.com/community/c6h1446842p30094086}

\begin{soln}
  We first solve part (a) and then use it to solve part (b).
  \begin{enumerate}[(a)]
    \item Since
      $|x|<\frac{1}{1+\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}}<1$
      we have
      $x^{i} \le |x|^{i} \le |x|\,\forall\,
      i \in \{1,2,\dots , n\}$.

      Now this implies
      $a_{i}x^{i} \ge -|a_{i}||x|\,\forall\,
      i \in \{1,2,\dots, n\}$,
      now this gives,
      \[
        \frac{Q(x)}{x^{k}} \ge 1-|x|
        \left( \sum_{i=1}^{n} |a_{i}|\right)
        \ge 1-\frac{ \sum_{i=1}^{n} |a_{i}|}
        {1+ \sum_{i=1}^{n} |a_{i}|}
        =\frac{1}{1+ \sum_{i=1}^{n} |a_{i}|} >0
      ,\]
      hence $\frac{Q(x)}{x^k}>0$ in the prescribed interval of $x$.
      
    \item We have $P(x)=x^{m}(\mathcal{H}(x))$,
      where $\mathcal{H}(x):=b_{m}+b_{m+1}x+
      \dots+b_{r}x^{r-m}$, now $\mathcal{H}(0) \neq 0$,
      and since $\mathcal{H}(x)$ is continuous at $0$,
      we have $\mathcal{H}(x)$ has a fixed sign on
      $(-\delta, \delta)$ for some $\delta>0$.
      But as $P(x)$ changes sign about $0$,
      we must have $x^{m}$ to change sign about
      $0 \iff m$ must be odd.
  \end{enumerate}
\end{soln}
